page.title: 01Introduction
page.content: The 12 sq km block takes in most of the parishes of Wenhaston and Thorington and part of the village and parish of Bramfield. It is largely farming land with some woodland and the remains of heathlands that in Suffolk are called Sandlings. The sandlings are underlain by glacial outwash sands and gravel. The settlements are ancient, being pre-Norman and have had a remarkably consistent population up to the beginning of the 20th century when a steady decline began. The parishes of Bramfield and Wenhaston each support their own primary schools, but Thorington has no nucleated settlement and consists of isolated farms. The farming is largely arable, but there is some fruit growing in the west of the block, and some cattle are kept on the water meadows by the streams.
